results.title: A Class of your own (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Richard Need, John R.F. Stewart and Stewart Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Instructional Techniques”.
Primarily designed for the instruction of the services, this film puts forward principles that are equally applicable to teaching in the civilian field. The instructor must plan their lessons in advance, whether in the classroom or at the workbench. The lesson should have a proper introduction, be developed logically, and flow naturally and interestingly to its concluding summary. The value of class activity, teaching aids, planned questions and proper note-taking are all dealt with in this film. The film falls into two parts: classroom instruction and practical instruction.

results.title: The Class of '01: the college of tomorrow
results.creator_credit: Peter Poor, Isaac Kleinerman and Columbia Broadcasting System
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “21st Century”.
A glimpse of what the universities of the future (2001) will be like. Examines new multi-media methods such as computerised control centres and closed circuit TV. Community colleges and the possible “bottling in film” of great professors are explained. Advanced methods of teacher training and new educational technologies are shown, and the question of what will happen to the creative processes in tomorrow’s classrooms is explored. Reporter: Walter Cronkite.

results.title: Clash of opinion
results.creator_credit: Margaret Smith, Gregory Clegg and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Personnel Management”.
Discusses the role of personnel management in industrial disputes. A dispute between management and members of a Transport Union is examined. A panel of directors of companies, trade unionists and personnel managers give opinions of how the dispute arose. Stresses the need for good communications between employers and unions and better education on negotiation for shop stewards. A good personnel manager can play an important day to day role in the creation of good relations between workers and management over a long period.

results.title: The Clarinet. Pt. 2
results.creator_credit: Muir Mathieson, Ken Cameron, EFVA and World Mirror-Realist Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “We Make Music”.
Jack Brymer of the BBC Symphony Orchestra talks about the history of the clarinet. He demonstrates all the instruments which form the clarinet family, from the high E flat to the contra bass, showing how they work and how to play them. Director Muir Mathieson was music director/composer for Sir Alexander Korda’s London films in the 1930s and 1940s.

results.title: Clarinet and bass clarinet
results.creator_credit: Milton Ingerson, Malcolm Smith and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Basic Music Techniques”.
One of a series of films designed to assist the musician and the music lover. In this film professional musicians show how the clarinet and bass clarinet are played, demonstrate their range and tone, and show how to care for them.

results.title: The Claim
results.brief_description: About some of the processes of industrial negotiations. The progress of a log of claims is followed from its inception in the work place through its many stages of direct negotiations with the employer or through the process of conciliation and arbitration.

results.title: A Civilised malady
results.brief_description: An investigation of the causes, incidence, social impact and cures of one of modern civilisations most insidious diseases, high blood pressure. Common salt is suspected of being the prime cause of this disease. In Australia one in six adults suffer from hypertension, but only half of those affected know that they have it.

results.title: Civil rights movement: Mississippi Summer Project
results.brief_description: Depicts the Civil Rights movement and the Summer Project of 1963 in a single community in Mississippi and highlights vital issues, such as the freedom schools set up by volunteers, labour exploitation, police brutality, voter registration and the challenge of achieving racial peace. Edited from the Richard Beymer presentation - “A Regular bouquet”.
results.description: Depicts the Civil Rights movement and the Summer Project of 1963 in a single community in Mississippi and highlights vital issues, such as the freedom schools set up by volunteers, labour exploitation, police brutality, voter registration and the challenge of achieving racial peace. results.title: Civil engineering
results.creator_credit: Career Productions and Mutual Life and Citizens' Assurance Co.
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Is this your career series”.
By showing civil engineers at work, the wide ramifications of their profession are indicated, from specialists in investigation, to those who handle design, detailed planning, or administration. The need for mathematical ability, and an understanding of the properties of materials emerges.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Career Productions and Mutual Life and Citizens’ Assurance Co.
